head.title: Antiques Clusters, Less Time-Gobbling, Replace Some Shops

hedline.hl1: Antiques Clusters, Less Time-Gobbling, Replace Some Shops

abstract.p: Multidealer antiques centers in Stamford, Conn, described; photos (S)

MULTIDEALER antiques centers are not only springing up but also seeming to beget one another. The Antique and Artisan Center opened on Jefferson Street in Stamford a year and a half ago, and was followed in August of this year by Hiden Galleries, one block west on Canal Street. A third, also on Canal Street is the Stamford Antiques Center, opened Jan. 1 to much fanfare -- brunch, drinks and dancing in the aisles amidst their reason for being, antiques and collectibles from 158 dealers.

In Darien, Bonnie Morgan, said she had to decide whether to invest her money in a business or home, and opted for the former. She rented a schoolhouse dating to the 1800's and converted it into an antiques center, called Morgan's, with space for 17 dealers on Tokeneke Road. The white-on-white hands-on environment with stall collections, jewelry, painted furniture, a little bit of everything, has been open since July 1.
In Ridgefield, Judith Baxter opened De Ja Vu, an antiques supermarket of 15 dealers in a Victorian house on Catoonah Avenue (half a block from Main Street) one and a half years ago.
Each center has a slightly different atmosphere and direction, but all are places for discovery and a trip down nostalgia lane.

For shoppers, the centers represent concentrated havens. For dealers, they spell freedom from minding the shop. One dealer, Muriel Neufeld, is displaying at three centers: Morgan's, the Antique and Artisan Center and now the Stamford Antiques Center, after closing her own Gilded Lily Antiques Shop in Cos Cob at the end of December.

''There wasn't enough visibility, which made it fail,'' said Ms. Neufeld, known for vintage costume jewelry, beaded and needlepoint purses and small furniture. ''So I decided to go into another multidealer place and free up my time. I'm responsible for having the booths look fresh and buying new merchandise. The centers,'' she added, ''have ready-made traffic. They do a lot of advertising.''

Although Ron Scinto and his partner, Mark Candid, claim no previous experience in the antiques business, they had a vision -- to fill a void by opening the first antiques center in the warehouse section of downtown Stamford. ''Everybody said it wouldn't fly here, but we brought it about,'' said Mr. Scinto.

They opened the Antique and Artisan Center at 69 Jefferson Street in 1996; they have 99 dealers and a waiting list. The 22,000-square-foot center is divided into three sections with 60 room settings. The middle post-and-beam section was an ice house during the turn of the century and trains pulled up to their loading docks. Among the center's displays are 18th- through 20th-century works, Art Deco, Art Moderne and folk art; primarily, however, the center's dealers focus on furniture.
''We changed the way people antique in New England,'' Mr. Scinto said. ''There's enough here to warrant a visit. It's a phenomenon. And we've spawned two other centers.''

John Hiden, of Hiden Galleries on Canal Street, who formerly had a booth at the Antique and Artisan Center, said he's been collecting since he was 6 years old. ''I picked garbage,'' said Mr. Hiden. ''Gradually over time the quality went up.''
Today Mr. Hiden, who also gained experience working for Braswell Antiques, an auction house in Norwalk, collects American and Continental furniture, lighting, mirrors and decorative accessories.

''The Antique and Artisan Center was the pioneer megacenter here,'' Mr. Hiden acknowledged. ''they put the area on the map.'' Hiden Galleries has 65 dealers in 16,000 square feet of a former laminations factory that Mr. Hiden gutted, stripped and painted, adding classical columns to create architectural interest.

Debbie Schwartz, 28, who has opened the latest and largest of this hub, the Stamford Antiques Center, said for her it started in the carriage. ''I'm a third-generation antiques dealer. My grandparents sold Tiffany lamps, my parents were called 'second generation antiques.' '' And her mother, Jeri Schwartz, has written books on antiques, is a columnist for Country Living magazine and a licensed appraiser. Ms. Schwartz sold her mail-order auction catalogue business last January in order to start this venture.

The one-time factory, originally Yale & Towne Manufacturing Company, retains its sense of history with pillars and a sawtoothed roof with hundreds of skylights. The ceiling is painted burgundy, walls candlelight white, concrete floors honey-colored, the colors compliments of Gordon McCunis and Jay Kobrin of Micunis Designs, interior designers who have taken a booth to display fabrics, pillows, paintings and furniture. Before the opening, Ms. Schwartz said, the two dealers' showcase collection of brassware (from 25-cent picture hooks to a set of eight 1820's tie backs at $4,000) was ''causing a commotion.''

Two outer aisles are filled with dealers' booths, chandeliers suspended from the ceiling stretching the length of one aisle into infinity. A center aisle is devoted to eye-stopping showcases of museum-quality antiques like jeweled Faberge-type picture frames.

''We have high end up to Tiffany lamps and then linen for $10,'' Ms. Schwartz said. ''We display jewelry, silver, blue and white porcelain, samplers, every single century furniture. You name it, we have it.
''Antiques dealers don't always come for one place but will make time for three. They can spend the day. This is antique heaven.''
